title: RS20425
content: The 1999 Satellite Home Viewer Improvement Act (SHVIA) expands provisions of the 1988 Satellite Home Viewer Act (SHVA) regarding consumer reception of television signals via satellite dishes. Major companies like EchoStar and DirecTV offer satellite television services through their DBS systems. Rainbow DBS, a subsidiary of Cablevision, also provides satellite channels through a service called Voom. SHVIA allows consumers greater access to broadcast network television programming via satellite dishes. The 1999 law, SHVIA, allows satellite companies to rebroadcast local network signals in the same market area, in addition to distant network signals. Understanding the distinction between local and distant network signals is crucial for SHVIA compliance. The SHVIA law allows satellite companies to rebroadcast local and distant network signals. Local signals are received within a network affiliate's local area, while distant signals come from elsewhere in the country. Consumers living outside the Grade B contour can receive distant network signals via satellite. The SHVA law established criteria for receiving distant network signals via satellite, based on the Grade B contour. Consumers inside the contour were not eligible, while those outside could receive the signals. Court challenges arose when some satellite companies transmitted signals to ineligible consumers, leading to over 2 million terminations. The FCC uses the Grade B intensity standard established by SHVIA for predicting signal strength. Consumers can seek a waiver from their satellite company to receive distant network signals if they believe they are not getting Grade A or Grade B signals. The local network affiliate has 30 days to decide on granting the waiver. The satellite company forwards waiver requests to the local network affiliate, who has 30 days to decide. If the waiver is granted or no action is taken, consumers may receive distant network signals. If denied, consumers can request a signal intensity test at no cost to them. Costs for the test are covered by the "loser" of the test, or by other agreed-upon methods. Exceptions are made for recreational vehicles. "Local-into-local" service is permitted for DBS companies to transmit local broadcast TV signals to consumers in the designated market area. The Satellite Home Viewer Improvement Act (SHVIA) allows dishes to receive distant network signals indefinitely if they were receiving them before October 31, 1999. DBS companies may provide "local-into-local" service in designated market areas, but are not required to do so. The law also includes a "must carry" provision, where DBS companies must carry all local broadcast stations in a market if they choose to provide any local station in that market. DBS companies must provide all local broadcast stations in a market if they offer any local station in that market. This requirement, known as the "must carry" provision, went into effect on January 1, 2002. Despite opposition from DBS companies, they are obligated to carry all local TV stations in a market that wish to be carried, with exceptions for duplicative programming and educational stations. Cable companies were already subject to similar rules based on the size of their systems. As of October 2004, EchoStar offered local-into-local service in 152 markets and DirecTV in 106 markets. In 1999, H.R. 1554 proposed a loan guarantee program for small and rural markets, but it was removed due to objections by Senator Gramm. Congress later passed the "Launching Our Communities Access to Local Television Act" (LOCAL) as Title X of the FY2001 Commerce-Justice-State Appropriations Act. The "Launching Our Communities Access to Local Television Act" (LOCAL) was passed by Congress as Title X of the FY2001 Commerce-Justice-State Appropriations Act. It created a board to select recipients of loan guarantees for up to $1.25 billion in loans to build systems for consumers to receive local television signals nationwide, prioritizing "nonserved" or "underserved" areas. The LOCAL Television Loan Guarantee Program, established by Congress, aims to provide loan guarantees of up to $1.25 billion for projects that ensure nationwide access to local television signals. The program prioritizes serving "nonserved" or "underserved" areas and providing high-speed Internet access. The Board issued regulations for the program in December 2003, with an application period ending in April 2004. Only one incomplete application was received, prompting the Board to return it and unanimously vote to reopen applications. The Board's website is http://www.usda.gov/rus/localtvboard/. The "Northpoint Provision" required FCC to conduct tests on terrestrial systems for interference with DBS satellites. The "Northpoint Provision" mandated FCC to test terrestrial systems for interference with DBS satellites. Northpoint Technology's subsidiary, Broadwave, seeks to offer TV programming and data services through a terrestrial wireless system called MVDDS.
